commentary.line: So England have gained early momentum in the 5-match series. The two sides will meet again for the second ODI at The Oval on Friday. Can England play a similar brand of cricket and do well? Or, will New Zealand bounce back in style? Brendon McCullum has said that fans can expect some exciting cricket from both sides for the rest of the series. Let's hope that we have a cracking game in a couple of days time. Until then, take care, goodbye!

Buttler: "With 400 on the board, we could be really attacking as they were under immense pressure. A really pleasing win. At 200/6 Brendon (McCullum) used up a lot of his frontline bowlers looking for the wickets of myself and Adil (Rashid) to try and bowl us out. I think we managed to get through that period which allowed us, in the last 10 overs, to really cash in. Adil bowled very well today. He spun the ball both ways and bowled with great control as well."
Jos Buttler is the Man of the Match

Morgan: "The guys were outstanding for us today. To come and hit the straps like that at the start of the series is outstanding, considering the group we have inside and what we asked them two days ago, we've certainly started well. The youngsters handled themselves very well. I know how tough it is for a young guy to play international cricket. Joe Root was outstanding, followed by an unbelievable innings from Jos Buttler. Adil (Rashid) can spin it both ways and he is a great asset to have in the side. I thought the guys were brilliant today. You can look back and say anything about the World Cup, but for me I am looking forward and I am really excited. Today, it encouraged me even more to look further down the line and give guys more of a chance to grow as cricketers. I think it is about 90-95 one-dayers before the next World Cup and the more games we can give our youngsters before then, the more experienced performances they can put in, it holds a lot of weight come the next World Cup. They (Billings and Roy) have been identified through a system, Sam Billings and Jason Roy are the calibre of athletes that we want in our one-day team and it's going to take them some time to settle."

McCullum: "The game changed pretty quickly. Joe Root and Jos Buttler were outstanding. I think it didn't swing much. They were outstanding with the bat and ball, it was a complete performance from England and we've got some work to do. You've got to accept when you get it wrong. The way the ball was holding up in the second innings showed that we got the toss wrong. We had to take wickets and to reduce them to 200 odd for 6 was good, but they played with no fear and put on a great partnership. We need to get a bit more accurate with the ball. We didn't expect that they would get 400. We created a couple of opportunities but then the game quickly slipped away from us. Tim (Southee) should be fine for the next one. The last time we played England, we were on the right side of things of a one-sided affair, today we are not. I think the crowds are going to witness some exciting cricket in the next few weeks."

Ross Taylor and Grant Elliott shared a fifty partnership, but the latter was run-out attempting a needless second run to give England the advantage. Rashid then removed debutant Mitchell Santner and Luke Ronchi off successive balls to put his side on top and soon New Zealand lost their way and lost the game by a massive margin of 210 runs. In fact, they lost their last 6 wickets for 13 runs.

Chasing 409, the visitors did not get off to the best of starts as they lost skipper Brendon McCullum in the very first over of the innings. When McCullum hit back-to-back fours off Steve Finn, it looked like he was continuing from where he left at the Cake Tin - McCullum thrashed Finn to all corners in that World Cup game - but the tall bowler bounced back in style by knocking McCullum's off pole out off the very next ball. Martin Guptill and Kane Williamson attacked for a while, but the former threw his wicket away. Williamson looked good, but perished while trying to up the ante.

What a game for this team, which has been termed as "New England." After a disastrous 2015 World Cup, the pressure was on England to prove their mettle in ODIs and the new look team has registered a massive win against New Zealand, who thrashed them in the multi-nation event a few months ago.

The England team is extremely happy and why not. The hosts form a huddle as they congratulate each other. The dressing room is absolutely ecstatic as well. The New Zealand players come out and shake hands with the home side. Meanwhile, a section of the crowd is seen dancing as they celebrate this huge win.

31.1   Jordan to McClenaghan, out Caught by Hales!! In the airrrrr and that's straight to the man in the deep. This is the largest victory in terms of runs for England in ODIs. Good length delivery on the leg stump, McClenaghan flicks, doesn't bother to keep it down and deep mid-wicket didn't have to move an inch. Hales has his hands aloft after taking the catch as the crowd celebrate in the background. McClenaghan c Hales b Jordan 2(2)
Jordan to McClenaghan, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

Nathan McCullum c Jordan b Finn 5(10) [4s-1]

28.2   Finn to Ross Taylor, out Lbw!! This is a big blow, probably the end of the Kiwi hopes, if there were any left till now. Full and angling in on middle stump line, Taylor goes across and misses the clip, wears it on the pad and the umpire raised his finger after giving it a thought. Taylor reviewed it, but it was clipping the leg stump. Ross Taylor lbw b Finn 57(54) [4s-5 6s-1]
Finn to Ross Taylor, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

Taylor has been given out lbw. He has decided to review it. The front foot is fine. 'There seems to be no bat involved. There is nothing on RTS. We have double checked that. Can we go to ball tracking please? It's pitching in line, hitting in line and it's umpire's call at the wickets as it is clipping leg stump,' says the third umpire. The original decision is upheld.

Hello again. New Zealand have their task cut out. With the brand of cricket they are playing, we can expect them to come hard at this target. Guptill and Baz are out in the middle. England take the field after a small huddle. Finn has the new ball in his hand. He has couple of slips in place....

Buttler: "It was a great start for us. Right throughout the innings it was fantastic. It was how we wanted to play. It's a good wicket. It will be tough to defend and we'll have to bowl well as well. This knock boosts my confidence. It was really pleasing for us. Now we need to take wickets and win this game."

At that stage it looked like New Zealand will be able to contain the Englishmen for a below par total, but Rashid walked out and along with Buttler, both batsmen took the sails out of the Kiwi attack. Both of them played without any fear and kept finding the gaps, while the Black Caps bowlers kept banging it short. Both of them put on 177 for the 7th wicket, a record in ODIs, with Buttler cracking his second ODI ton off just 66 balls. He now owns the record for the fastest and the second fastest ODI hundred by an Englishman. Rashid too continued to play his shots, reaching his maiden ODI fifty in the process as well. Even though both Buttler and Rashid went trying to up the ante, two lusty blows from Plunkett saw England going past 400, their highest total in ODI history.

Root continued to play aggressively and soon reached his 5th ODI ton, that too off just 71 balls, making it the 3rd fastest ton by an Englishman at that time. Root though soon edged one off Boult and that opened the floodgates for New Zealand. After being 171/2 at one stage, England were stuttering at 202/6, when the debutant, Sam Billings was given out lbw on review.

England got off to the worst start possible, losing Jason Roy off the first ball of the innings. However, that didn't deter Hales and Root from playing their shots as both put on a 50-run stand before Hales top-edged a pull to Henry. Root though continued to play some brilliant shots and Morgan gave him good support from the other end. They put on 121 for the third wicket and their partnership was broken by McClenaghan, who trapped Morgan lbw after the English captain reached his fifty.

It's time for the action to begin. Alex Hales and Jason Roy make their way out to the middle. How many slips will Baz have for his new ball bowlers? He had at least three and sometimes four during the World Cup. Trent Boult to open the attack and he has only two slips in place.
New Zealand have rested Tim Southee for this game, while Corey Anderson, who missed the second Test, is yet to fully recover from a back injury.
Teams:

New Zealand (Playing XI): Martin Guptill, Brendon McCullum(c), Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott, Mitchell Santner, Luke Ronchi(w), Nathan McCullum, Matt Henry, Mitchell McClenaghan, Trent Boult
England (Playing XI): Alex Hales, Jason Roy, Joe Root, Eoin Morgan(c), Ben Stokes, Jos Buttler(w), Sam Billings, Adil Rashid, Chris Jordan, Liam Plunkett, Steven Finn

Morgan: "The last year or so has been really poor, but the future looks promising with a few young guys coming in. The group of players that we have picked can play the brand of cricket that we want to play moving forward. Sam Billings is making his debut, he is an exciting player and he's going to be very good to watch in the middle-order."

McCullum: "We are going to bowl first. The conditions are overcast, hopefully our boys can swing it early on and take some early wickets. Mitchell Santner is making his debut. This wicket looks great. I think overall our philosophy is still very much about playing a positive brand of cricket. The World Cup was outstanding for us. Now we've got an opportunity to continue the good work."
New Zealand have won the toss and have opted to field
It's toss time folks!

Although England are playing at home, the pressure is slightly more on them to put up an improved show in the 50-over format after a disastrous World Cup campaign. Team vice-captain and wicket-keeper Jos Buttler has asked his mates to play 'no-fear-cricket', while interim coach Paul Farbrace has said that the side needs to play with freedom in the 5-match ODI series. England have had a decent build-up to the series as a few of the players did well in the Natwest T20 Blast. However, they are not fielding a full strength squad as the likes of James Anderson, Stuart Broad, Ian Bell and Moeen Ali have been rested for the series.

England then made a few changes to their coaching staff, drew the Test series against West Indies, Andrew Strauss was appointed the new ECB director and then England played a hard-fought Test series against New Zealand in which they shared honours. After the conclusion of the Test series, McCullum said "1-1 was a fair reflection." New Zealand played a warm-up match against Leicestershire to practice for the ODI series, in which Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott and Luke Ronchi played aggressively. Taylor, who has not been in the best of forms of late, has hinted that he would make a conscious effort to be more positive with the bat.

The last time these two sides met in an ODI, Tim Southee picked up a record 7-wicket haul, while Brendon McCullum scored a breezy fifty. Yes, it was at the 2015 World Cup that New Zealand thrashed England at the Cake Tin in a game that lasted a total of just 45.4 overs. A lot has happened since then. McCullum continued to bludgeon bowling attacks at the top throughout the World Cup and then continued his show in the IPL as well. New Zealand had an excellent time at the multi-nation event, barring the final, while England failed to make it to the quarter-finals.

Preview:
After his team were thrashed by Australia in the World Cup final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on March 29, New Zealand captain Brendon McCullum was asked by a reporter if he and his team would change the aggressive brand of cricket that had taken them to their maiden tournament final, built on a stunning winning streak of ten matches.

His reply came fast, without hesitation. "No, no, you don't change your style of play," said McCullum with the same seriousness and conviction with which he had rolled up to every press conference during a memorable World Cup campaign. "For us to develop into the team that we want to be in international cricket, we have to play like that. I think there's an element of fearlessness about how we play, which has been an effect on other teams, as well, and I think if you ask most of the teams in this tournament what they think of how we've played the game, they would be very respectful of how we've gone about it.

"It's what gives us our greatest pleasure, as well, and sometimes we're going to come undone, but for us to compete against the big teams on regular occasions and for us to be able to develop into the team we want to be, we need to keep playing this brand of cricket, and we'll get better at doing it the more we become accustomed to it, and I guess a stronger depth of players we develop in the same sort of mould of cricket as we have. So yeah, we're not going to change."

That attacking, joyous brand of cricket was extended in the Test arena recently. New Zealand owned much of the first Test at Lord's by playing aggressive cricket, and it was during one such attacking passage that they let the match slip. But McCullum's men stuck to that same approach at Leeds and it earned them a 1-1 series scoreline to extend their unbeaten run further. Now, they will ditch the whites to don black, the colour they wore so passionately during the World Cup. The format in which they bossed opposing teams in the World Cup until the final, the format in which they are ranked third, the format in which they have the best chance to keep winning. England have reason to be worried. Very worried.

A run of ten unbeaten ODIs ended at the MCG on March 29, when a ruthless Australia shoved them aside for a fifth World Cup title. After two Tests against England, the Black Caps warmed up for the limited-overs leg of their tour with a 198-run hammering of Leicestershire on Friday. In that 50-over fixture, the tourists were in a spot of bother at 152 for 5 but surged to 373 without further loss through a superb partnership of 221 in just 25 overs from centurions Grant Elliott and Luke Ronchi.

Elliott is, of course, the allrounder who shone during that unforgettable World Cup semi-final at Eden Park on March 24, hitting the winning runs in a nail-biting chase over South Africa to spark scenes of delirium. Elliott followed that special innings with a brisk half-century in the final, the only innings of note from a limp New Zealand display. Now, as New Zealand and England begin a five-match series with the first ODI at Birmingham on June 9 (Tuesday), the likes of Elliott - not part of the Test squad - will hope to reproduce such batting form as the Black Caps get back to their strongest suite against a team which put up its most tepid World Cup campaign ever.

From the XI that played the World Cup final at the MCG, the most likely change will be Nathan McCullum coming in for the retired Daniel Vettori. Corey Anderson's back is being closely monitored, so should he not be passed fit then the spin-bowling allrounder Mitchell Santner could get a debut. With left-arm quick Mitchell McClenaghan joining the touring party from a successful IPL season of winners Mumbai, then taking four wickets against Leicestershire, New Zealand's bowling has added zing. Tim Southee, Trent Boult and Matt Henry bowled a lot of overs during the Tests and so having a fresh McClenaghan could be the way the team management tilts.

Eoin Morgan's England have lost seven of 11 ODIs this year, sitting at sixth on the ICC's list for ODI teams. The new selection panel dumped regulars James Anderson, Stuart Broad, Ian Bell and Gary Ballance while resting Moeen Ali, opting to bring in some fresh faces. There are some aggressive hitters in the new squad, but how they fare against a superb New Zealand bowling attack remains to be seen. It will not be easy.

During the World Cup, McCullum's Black Caps set the bar for all ODI teams apart from Australia. If they replicate that exciting and aggressive brand across the next two weeks, they should comfortably add another ODI series and a one-off Twenty20 international to their burgeoning kitty. So sit back and get ready to enjoy the ride.
Teams:
England (From): Alex Hales, Jason Roy, James Taylor, Joe Root, Eoin Morgan(c), Jos Buttler(w), Ben Stokes, Adil Rashid, Chris Jordan, Mark Wood, Steven Finn, Liam Plunkett, Sam Billings, David Willey

New Zealand (From): Brendon McCullum(c), Martin Guptill, Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Corey Anderson, Grant Elliott, Luke Ronchi(w), Nathan McCullum, Tim Southee, Mitchell McClenaghan, Trent Boult, Matt Henry, Tom Latham, Mitchell Santner, Ben Wheeler
